model#

class Crowding.model.CrowdingEstimator(cov_func_curry=<class 'Crowding.cov.Matern52'>, n_landmarks=5000, rank=0.999, method='auto', jitter=1e-06, sigma2=1e-06, n_iter=100, init_learn_rate=1, inference_func=<function run_inference>, landmarks=None, nn_distances=None, d=None, mu=None, ls=None, cov_func=None, L=None, initial_value=None)#

Bases: object

A non-parametric density estimator. CrowdingEstimator performs Bayesian inference with a Gaussian process prior and Nearest Neighbor likelihood. All intermediate computations are cached as instance variables, so the user can access intermediate results and change some parameters without recomputing every step. See usage.

Parameters:

  • cov_func_curry (function or type) – Generator of the Gaussian process covariance function. Must be a curry that takes one length scale argument and returns a covariance function of the form k(x, y) \(\rightarrow\) float. Defaults to the type Matern52.

  • n_landmarks (int) – Number of landmark points. If less than 1 or greater than or equal to the number of training points, does not compute or use inducing points. Defaults to 5000.

  • rank (int or float) – The rank of the covariance matrix. If rank is equal to the number of datapoints, the covariance matrix is exact and full rank. If rank is equal to the number of landmark points, the standard Nystrom approximation is used. If rank is a float greater than 0 and less than 1, the rank is reduced further using the QR decomposition such that the eigenvalues of the included eigenvectors account for the specified percentage of the total eigenvalues. Defaults to 0.999.

  • method (str) – Explicitly specifies whether rank is to be interpreted as a fixed number of eigenvectors or a percent of eigenvalues to include in the low rank approximation. Supports ‘fixed’, ‘percent’, or ‘auto’. If ‘auto’, interprets rank as a fixed number of eigenvectors if it is an int and interprets rank as a percent of eigenvalues if it is a float. Provided for explictness and to clarify the ambiguous case of 1 vs 1.0. Defaults to ‘auto’.

  • jitter (float) – A small amount to add to the diagonal of the covariance matrix for numerical stabilitity. Defaults to 1e-6.

  • sigma2 (float) – White noise variance for the case the rank is reduced further than the number of landmark points. Ignored in other cases. Must be greater than 0. Defaults to 1e-6.

  • n_iter (int) – Number of optimization iterations. Defaults to 100.

  • init_learn_rate (float) – Initial learn rate. Defaults to 1.

  • inference_func (function) – Function that performs Bayesian inference. The signature must be (loss_func, initial_value, n_iter=n_iter, init_learn_rate=init_learn_rate) \(\rightarrow\) (pre_transformation, optimize_results). pre_transformation is the vector of parameters of the optimization at the final step and optimize_results contains any other results to save. Defaults to run_inference from the inference module.

  • landmarks (array-like or None) – Points to quantize the data for the approximate covariance. If None, landmarks are set as k-means centroids with k=n_landmarks. Ignored if n_landmarks is greater than or equal to the number of training points. Defaults to None.

  • nn_distances (array-like or None) – Precomputed nearest neighbor distances at each data point. If None, computes the nearest neighbor distances automatically, with a KDTree if the dimensionality of the data is less than 20, or a BallTree otherwise. Defaults to None.

  • d (int or None) – Local dimensionality of the data. If None, sets d to the size of axis 1 of the training data points. Defaults to None.

  • mu (float or None) – Mean of the Gaussian process. If None, sets mu to the 1th percentile of \(mle(nn\text{_}distances, d) - 10\), where \(mle = \log(\text{gamma}(d/2 + 1)) - (d/2) \cdot \log(\pi) - d \cdot \log(nn\text{_}distances)\). Defaults to None.

  • ls (float or None) – Length scale of the Gaussian process covariance function. If None, sets ls to the geometric mean of the nearest neighbor distances times a constant. If cov_func is supplied explictly, ls has no effect. Defaults to None.

  • cov_func (function or None) – Gaussian process covariance function of the form k(x, y) \(\rightarrow\) float. If None, automatically generates the covariance function cov_func = cov_func_curry(ls). Defaults to None.

  • L (array-like or None) – A matrix such that \(L L^T \approx K\), where \(K\) is the covariance matrix. If None, automatically computes L. Defaults to None.

  • initial_value (array-like or None) – Initial guess for Maximum A Posteriori optimization. If None, finds \(z\) that minimizes \(||Lz + mu - mle|| + ||z||\), where \(mle = \log(\text{gamma}(d/2 + 1)) - (d/2) \cdot \log(\pi) - d \cdot \log(nn\text{_}distances)\), where \(d\) is the dimensionality of the data. Defaults to None.

Variables:

  • cov_func_curry – Generator of the Gaussian process covariance function.

  • n_landmarks – Number of landmark points.

  • rank – Rank of approximate covariance matrix or percentage of eigenvalues included in approximate covariance matrix.

  • method – Method to interpret the rank as a fixed number of eigenvectors or a percentage of eigenvalues.

  • jitter – A small amount added to the diagonal of the covariance matrix for numerical stability.

  • sigma2 – White noise variance for the case the rank is reduced further than the number of landmark points.

  • landmarks – Points to quantize the data.

  • nn_distances – Nearest neighbor distances for each data point.

  • d – Local dimensionality of the data.

  • mu – Gaussian process mean.

  • ls – Gaussian process covariance function length scale.

  • cov_func – Gaussian process covariance function.

  • L – A matrix such that \(L L^T \approx K\), where \(K\) is the covariance matrix.

  • initial_value – Initial guess for Maximum A Posteriori optimization.

  • x – The training data.

  • transform – A function \(z \sim \text{Normal}(0, I) \rightarrow \text{Normal}(mu, K')\).

  • loss_func – Bayesian loss function.

  • pre_transformation – \(z \sim \text{Normal}(0, I)\) before transformation to \(\text{Normal}(mu, K')\), where \(I\) is the identity matrix and \(K'\) is the approximate covariance matrix.

  • optimize_result – All results from the optimization. By default is a tuple containing the last step of the optimization and the Bayesian losses at each step.

  • log_density_x – Log density at the training points.

  • log_density_func – Computes the log density at arbitrary prediction points.

fit(x)#

Perform Bayesian Inference.

Parameters:

x (array-like) – Training instances to estimate density function.

Returns:

self - A fitted instance of this estimator.

Return type:

Object

fit_predict(x)#

Perform Bayesian inference and return the log density at training points.

Parameters:

x (array-like) – Training instances to estimate density function.

Returns:

log_density_x - The log density at each training point in x.

predict(x)#

Predict the log density at each point in x. Note that in the case that the rank is reduced below the number of landmark points, predictions at the original training points may differ slightly from fit_predict due to the sigma2 noise.

Parameters:

x (array-like) – New data to predict.

Returns:

log_density - The log density at each test point in x.

Return type:

array-like

recursive_setattr(attribute, value)#

If value is different from the current value of attribute, sets attribute to value and sets any other attributes that depend on attribute and were computed implicitly to None. If value is the current value of attribute, has no effect. Equality is determined by the ‘is’ keyword.

Parameters:

  • attribute (string) – The name of the attribute.

  • value (anything) – The value to set attribute to.
